It says in the manual that 

"if the Document Root is Relative path , that it will be relative to the SERVERROOT"


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
i have 

ServerRoot "c:/Apache2"
DocumentRoot "/"             (This is relative)


The entire c:\ drive is shown in brower for http://localhost  as expected
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

also if no SERVERROOT is specified and  Document Root is relative it is then 
relative to the serverroot

#ServerRoot
DocumentRoot "htdocs"               (this is relative path)


Now only files in the c:\apache2\htdocs folder are shown at http://localhost

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

       This is not clear in the manual that regardless of the server root being set that   relative paths are relative to the server root.   

and there is no way of setting the document root =  serverroot using relative paths because the document root cannot be left empty.

Changing to docs/enhancement.

Often compiled-in defaults are used in the absence of explicit configuration.  Sometimes it's not clear that the "Default" values for a directive are based on how you build or the platform.

Discussion about figuring out how all this works belongs on  users@httpd.apache.org, not in bugzilla.

If you think there's a[nother] bug, go ahead and open it. If you're not sure, discuss it on the mailing list first.

creator: rbowen@apache.org
text:
"/" is not a relative path. It's an absolute path, even on Windows. On Windows, "/" means "the root of whatever drive your ServerRoot is on", while you need to specify the drive letter "D:/" when you mean "a different drive from my ServerRoot."

As for ServerRoot, if you don't specify it in the configuration file, it defaults to what was provided at build time, if anything, or to the per-platform default value. In the case of Windows, this is C:/apache2

I'll take a look at the docs referred to, but what you are describing seems to be completely consistent with the documentation you are quoting.

If you have a specific suggestion as to how we could make this clearer, please feel free to share that with us.

In r1160342, I've added a remark to the ServerRoot docs regarding the --prefix argument to configure, and the fact that most third-party distros of the server see fit to change the default location of ServerRoot. It is always the case that an omitted directive results in the default valud of that directive being used. In your case, the default is c:/Apache2. There's always a compiled-in default for ServerRoot, so if you don't specify, that's what gets used.
